page.title: 02Landscape Around Treviscoe
page.content: The unique appearance of the area which is often described as{"lunar {landscape"}is caused by the enormous upheavals of the clay industry. It has been given the name{"Cornish Alps". } The clay itself is obtained from areas of old and "decaying" granite. Maps of the area soon become outdated as houses and roads are buried and new routes created to replace them. Modern workings create enormous white tips, cavernous pits and large white mica lagoons. In contrast the older workings are covered in the green of gorse and rough grass. Steep sided pits are filled with deep green water. There are many old pump houses. When not covered by mist, glimpses of the sea can be obtained from various vantage points.Southwards stretch rolling hills of farmland.Farms in the area are predominately of grassland.
